We are told to engage in self- care to avoid burnout but they didn't actually care.

review_title: I loved my crew but IT leadership needs a serious Investigation.
job_title: IT Support Analyst in Indianapolis, IN
pros: My coworkers were amazing, hard working people. The company itself has fantastic values.
cons: IT leadership. One of the most baffling things I've ever seen. IT leads get away with doing little to no work, and make costly mistakes due to gross negligence (not honest mistakes). They get away with belittling their subordinates and writing them up for things that do not have a foundation of misconduct. (I know I used to manage an IT department for several years, I know what they should and should not do.) They fake their knowledge and do anything to look good for upper leadership. On the outside they appear incredibly high functioning. They fired someone for writing "blue lives matter" in a place of almost no visibility. They fired another for simply being frustrated with leadership and unable to use his incredible talents to further the department, he was instead silenced. They tell you certain certifications are REQUIRED to move up in the company when some leadership have no certifications at all. They'd rather hire outside than promote. They hid that a certain member of Chief's watched adult content on his computer at work. They say things like "maybe you should reconsider your career" when asking about advice to move into the next role of the department up. When bringing up concerns one member of leadership actually said "if you don't like it here you can go somewhere else". One helpdesk guy talked to the CTO about taking time off for a new baby he was going to have. The CTO said "of course, even though you won't have PTO you can absolutely take 2 weeks" only then for him to have the baby at 2am and get a text at noon the same day saying "where are you?" (and after explaining he had a baby) "If you're not in here before the end of this day, we will have to take appropriate disciplinary action". The company implemented a flex schedule last year, It was too confusing for leadership so they just decided that the department doesn't get that benefit. There are literally hundreds of other events I could explain but I'd have to write a small novel and publish it. It's seriously almost other-worldly what goes on behind the scenes.

review_title: A good company with some deficits
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Indianapolis, IN
pros: The company has many great benefits (generous PTO, flexible work hours, health benefits, etc.) Training opportunities and encouraged to attended outside trainings, a supportive team.
cons: High billing standard that interferes with attending quarterly supervision and other mandatory trainings through the agency. There are limited opportunities to participate in team building. Low mileage reimbursement and low pay for the tasks and challenges that are apparent.

job_title: Skills Development Specialist in Greenwood, IN
pros: Coworkers are friendly and helpful, the schedule can be flexible to an extent, everyday is different, no weekends
cons: Low pay, competition among employees, stress of having to meet service delivery requirements, monthly and bi-weekly meetings, dealing with cancellations is stressful when you have a quota to meet, the company frequently adds more responsibility to this position but does not increase compensation

review_title: There were lots of transitions which was confusing at times but overall a great place to work.
job_title: Skills Development Specialist in Indianapolis, IN
pros: Mileage reimbursement and pay is more than other mental health jobs. The ability to work individually or as a team. Good clinical support.
cons: Lots of staff transitions, it was hard to find quality people to hire. The company seemed to value saving money more and changed our billing expectations to reduce services given and increased the case load, so that was a con.

job_title: Skills Development Specialist in Indianapolis, IN
pros:
The goals of the organization are  worthy. Lots of kids in the school based program need lots of help and A&C can provide that support so the Educators can do their own jobs. Some kids would not make it if it weren't for the extra help they receive through this organization. Their ultimate goal and mission is a good one. 

For employees, the company provides free Starbucks coffee, fruit, and tea.  Small tokens of recognition for employees including snacks at meetings, birthday cards and small gifts under $5. 

Mileage is paid at a higher rate than other organizations if picking up or dropping off a kid. Upgrades in technology help make the job easier. Some team leaders are great (others are not ).
cons:
Numbers, numbers, numbers! Sadly, this job is all about the numbers. If you don't meet productivity standards of working with kids at least five hours each day then you quickly fall behind and it's incredibly difficult to catch up. If you continue having trouble hitting your "productivity numbers" and you get too far behind they will let you go. Documentation for time with these kids is separate but required so you'd better find a way to make it work. 

They seem to have lots of hiring events. Then they hire a bunch of people and spend money and resources running them through the training program. Due to the constant stream of people being fired or resigning (all very civil like) they just put out some more job ads within 24 hours and spend more money to train more people $$$$, 

There's no room for a learning curve outside of the first 8 weeks of training. Once you're out there you are expected to maintain or exceed the quotas. Having a bad day? Feeling ill? Snow day? Forced to attend a meeting? Too bad. You have to make your quotas regardless.  

This organization is run very much like a business despite the nonprofit tax status. I understand they need to make money. However, I often had to  push aside someone who needed help because I couldn't bill for my time with them.  I did hear they used to have slightly lower billing requirements which (on top of all of the documentation required for the job) would have made the job easier, but it seems every new thing they establish is designed to make more money. At some point they will become more FOR profit than NON profit.  It always made me feel like a cog in a machine. If I wanted to meet high metrics  I would have worked in the business world and made a heck of a lot more money doing it.  Often I felt like a sheep in wolf's clothing.

Health insurance and benefits are OK. They really push the high deductible plan but as I found out, it's not as great as they claim it is.  Salary is OK. No raises unless you are promoted to a manager position. Minor benefits to billing over the requirements which ultimately equals only a couple hundred dollars "bonus" each quarter. Incredibly high turnover rate. They asked us point blank if we have "ever thought about quitting A&C" and "why?" Their retention efforts seemed more like a weed out process of the "weak" ones who could defect.

review_title: Felt like an assembly line where the focus was on how many clients I saw daily & not on providing quality services.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Indianapolis, IN
pros:
1.	Pay is very good compared to other agencies
2.	Access to HSPP & MD’s for feedback with interventions and treatment plans
3.	The online training program that the agency uses Relias provides opportunity for free CEU continuing education units accessible at any time which is good for licensed clinical mental health staff and medical staff that need CEU’s to keep up with their license
cons:
1.	Office politics leads to back stabbing , micromanagement
2.	Egos of many staff office hinders quality of work. The level of insecurity of some directors and staff have when giving feedback is pathetic. Brevity is key when communicating there because often many will not read emails in there entirely and are incapable of taking content and context in consideration. 
3.	Poor leadership from majority of directors with regards to communication, advocacy, mentoring, and investing in working with staff to problem solve 
4.	Tedious paperwork that is time consuming
5.	Treat you like you are disposable

job_title: School Based Therapist in Greenwood, IN
pros: Good benefits. Room to advance within company. Most other employees are nice to work with. Working with kids in the school is great.
cons: Training is horrible. They make you drive all over Indianapolis instead setting a location and have trainers come to the cohort. Most are redundant anyway. Supervisor is nearly impossible to contact and serves no help even when you can. There is no teamwork here. Company and school expects you to work miracles.

review_title: The Focus is on Quota — NOT quality
job_title: Therapist in Sydney
pros: Great Benefits. Good clinical training provided up front which was a great refresher for evidenced-based care. The administrative offices have Starbucks coffee machines.
cons: Emphasis (after the 75 day training) is centered on billing, getting weekly quota met  The quota is a weighted “unit” that roughly translated into 87% of an 8 hour work day for therapists. Staff is micromanaged to the point of being told “here are the phrases you are to use in documentation”  Very high turnover due to both employees quitting and high number of terminations (firing). Salary is low end, comparatively.

job_title: School Based Therapist in Perth, Western Australia
pros: Good PTO, extensive training and resources. Okay for experience right out of college. Opportunity for advancement if you can get through the first year.
cons: Must account for every single minute. School based therapy is not based on school hours which means keeping kids afterschool and lots of running. No support from team leader, very cliquey in the office. Pay is awful, no work/life balance. Not enough time or opportunity to chart during all sessions which means charting after hours.

review_title: It is WHO you know not WHAT you know
job_title: Help Desk Analyst in Adelaide

cons: Very cut throat place to work. Management makes decision based on who is their friend rather than skill level or job proficiency.  If you complain or say anything negative about your job or the bosses' pet they find a reason to fire you.  You can be totally incompetent and late every day if the boss likes you and then get promoted even though you lack the basic skills and certifications required to do the job.

job_title: Staff Therapist in Indianapolis, IN

Worst place I’ve ever worked! It’s a mess from the CEO down. Be smart & choose another place to work.
